speaker: therapist
text: Hello Alex, welcome back. Last session was quite intensive—we touched on core beliefs and defusion. I’d like to start today by checking in on how that multi-layered practice went, and how you’ve been feeling generally this past week.

speaker: client
text: Hi. It’s been… a week of ups and downs, but different. The downs didn’t feel as bottomless. I used the ‘I’m having the thought that…’ phrase a lot. It’s becoming kind of automatic, which is weirdly helpful.

speaker: therapist
text: That’s not weird at all—that’s the brain building a new neural pathway. When a tool starts to feel automatic, it means it’s becoming integrated. That’s excellent progress. Were there any specific situations where you noticed this new response making a tangible difference?

speaker: client
text: Yes. I had to give feedback to a colleague on their part of a project. Old me would have agonized for days, drafting and redrafting the email, sure they’d hate me. This time, the thought came: ‘They’ll think you’re arrogant and nitpicky.’ I immediately heard it in my mind as ‘I’m having the thought that they’ll think I’m arrogant.’ It… took the sting out. I wrote a clear, polite email in 15 minutes and sent it.

speaker: therapist
text: That is a textbook example of defusion leading to valued action. You didn’t get rid of the anxiety; you changed your relationship to it so it didn’t dictate your behavior. This is a core goal. And the outcome?

speaker: client
text: They wrote back, ‘Thanks, good points.’ No drama at all. It was almost anticlimactic.

speaker: therapist
text: Anticlimactic is the ideal outcome for anxiety! It proves the feared catastrophe isn’t inevitable. Let’s explore the other layer: the core belief statement. You were to practice, ‘Even though I sometimes feel insecure, the evidence shows I am competent and capable.’ How did that land?

speaker: client
text: Honestly? It felt a bit stiff at first, like I was reciting a line. But I kept saying it in the morning. Mid-week, after that email exchange went fine, I said it and it felt… truer. Less like a lie I was telling myself.

speaker: therapist
text: That’s exactly how it works. We gather evidence through our actions—like sending that email—and then use that evidence to feed the new, more balanced belief. The statement bridges the logical evidence with the emotional feeling. Now, I’d like to shift our focus slightly today toward something we’ve touched on but not systematized: problem-solving. Anxiety often involves two types of worries—‘hypothetical’ what-ifs, and ‘practical’ problems we can actually tackle. Would it be helpful to learn a structured approach for the practical ones?

speaker: client
text: Yes, definitely. Sometimes my worry is about a real thing, like ‘I have too much work and might miss a deadline.’ My brain just spins on ‘I’m going to fail’ instead of actually solving it.

speaker: therapist
text: Perfect example. For those tangible concerns, we use a skill called Structured Problem-Solving. It has five steps. Let’s use your example: ‘I have too much work and might miss a deadline.’ Step 1 is to Define the problem as specifically as possible. Not ‘I’m failing,’ but ‘I have three project tasks due Friday and I’ve only completed one.’ Can you define it like that?

speaker: client
text: Okay. ‘I have to finish the budget report, the client slides, and the team update by Friday EOD. I’ve only done the team update. The budget report is the most complex and is blocking the slides.’

speaker: therapist
text: Excellent. That’s specific and factual. Step 2 is to Brainstorm all possible solutions—no judging, just generating ideas. Even silly ones. What comes to mind?

speaker: client
text: Uh… I could work late the next two nights. I could ask for a deadline extension. I could ask a colleague for help with the data part of the budget. I could… quit my job and move to a cabin. That’s the silly one.

speaker: therapist
text: All ideas are welcome in brainstorming. The cabin option is noted. Step 3 is to Evaluate the options. List pros and cons. Let’s take two: ‘Work late’ and ‘Ask for help.’ What are the pros and cons of each?

speaker: client
text: Working late: Pro—I get it done myself, maintain control. Con—I’ll be exhausted, stress will be high, my sleep will suffer. Asking for help: Pro—it might be faster, less stressful. Con—I feel vulnerable, I might be seen as incapable, I’d owe a favor.

speaker: therapist
text: Great evaluation. Step 4 is to Choose a solution and make an action plan. Based on this, which feels most effective and least damaging? Remember, ‘effective’ includes your mental well-being.

speaker: client
text: Asking for help is scarier but probably smarter. The action plan would be: identify which colleague is best with budgets, draft a clear ask for just the complex data part, and talk to them tomorrow morning.

speaker: therapist
text: That’s a clear, actionable plan. Step 5 is to Implement it and then Review the outcome. This structure does two things: it moves you out of emotional panic into executive function, and it gives you a behavioral alternative to worry. Now, let’s connect this back to your core belief. If you successfully ask for help and the problem gets solved, what does that do to the belief ‘I will be exposed as incompetent’?

speaker: client
text: It… challenges it. It shows that being competent sometimes means knowing your limits and collaborating. It’s not a sign of weakness; it’s a strategy.

speaker: therapist
text: Exactly. This is how behavioral change rewires beliefs. Now, I want to check in on the lifestyle support system. You mentioned walks. Have you noticed any resistance to doing them, or have they become more routine?

speaker: client
text: They’re becoming a habit. I listen to a podcast or just the sounds outside. It’s less about ‘I should exercise’ and more about ‘this is my mental reset time.’

speaker: therapist
text: That reframe is perfect. It’s now a valued self-care activity, not a chore. This is how sustainable change happens. So, for this week, I propose we add this Structured Problem-Solving to your toolkit. Your practice could be: 1) Continue defusion for automatic thoughts. 2) Use the 5-step problem-solving for one tangible worry that comes up. 3) Keep affirming your core belief with the new evidence you collect. Does that feel like a manageable integration?

speaker: client
text: It does. It feels like I’m building a full set of tools. Defusion for the mental noise, problem-solving for the real issues, and the core belief work as the foundation. And the walks to support it all.

speaker: therapist
text: You’ve summarized the entire integrated plan beautifully. What I’m hearing is a shift from feeling victimized by your anxiety to becoming an active manager of it. How does that feel, to hear yourself describe it that way?

speaker: client
text: It feels… powerful. And strange. I’m so used to being at the mercy of it. I’m not ‘cured’ or anything—I still get anxious—but I have a map now. I know what to do. It’s the difference between being lost in a storm and having a compass and shelter.

speaker: therapist
text: Alex, that is one of the most accurate and hopeful descriptions of therapeutic progress I’ve heard. You are building your own compass and shelter. That is the goal. You should feel very proud of the work you’re doing. Let’s continue to solidify these skills next week.

speaker: client
text: Thank you. I am proud. And tired. But it’s a good tired. I’ll see you next week.
